awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Imaging and Understanding the Kinetic Pathways in Shape-Anisotropic Nanoparticle Self-Assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:

An emerging theme in materials science is to understand and design artificial materials exhibiting the features of living organisms: adaptive and evolving functional behaviors. Examples include patterned ultra-small antennas that modulate local electromagnetic field strengths upon different sun positions, or automotive "skins" that optimize the aerodynamics of vehicles in varying environments. With support from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, the Principal Investigator's NSF CAREER grant is focused on deciphering the rules upon which nanometer-sized building blocks self-organize and reorganize into such adaptive materials. These building blocks are chosen due to the unique potential for miniaturization and the collective properties determined by the structures they organize into. The key enabling innovations of this project are two-fold. First, a novel imaging tool will be used to trace and videotape the building block motions on the fly at up to atomic resolution. Second, the obtained motions will be analyzed to interpret the crosstalk among these building blocks. The obtained fundamental understanding can also be applied to other systems composed of tiny elementary objects such as biological molecules which are critical for human health, or to create new materials that can achieve cheap and clean renewable energy. The project provides training to both undergraduate and graduate students. A "tri-M lab" including Modular lab demos, a Mobile game app, and Movies is utilized as a platform for broad dissemination to the general public.

Technical Abstract:

The Principal Investigator's long-term goal is to transmute inanimate materials into animate ones, capable of reconfiguring their structure and property on demand. The key challenge in designing reconfigurable materials from nanoscale building blocks lies in understanding the kinetic pathways of their self-assembly. These pathways define how building blocks interact and assemble into targeted structures, i.e. the building block nanoscale interaction-targeted structure relationship. However, the kinetic pathways are associated with how building blocks continuously diffuse and tumble in a solvent, which is both spatiotemporally varying and nanoscopic in nature. Thus, fully understanding these pathways requires real-space, in-situ characterization with high spatiotemporal resolution, which is not offered by existing ex-situ and ensemble methods. The research objective of this CAREER proposal is thus to address this challenge and to quantify the interactions and kinetic pathways governing self-assembly and structural reconfiguration in model systems of anisotropic gold nanoparticles (NPs). The proposed approach is to combine the emergent liquid-phase transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with automated movie analysis methods developed in the PI's group to quantify the dynamics of NP self-assembly. Specifically, this research will (i) capture the self-assembly trajectories of representative anisotropic NPs using low-dose liquid-phase TEM with nanometer and millisecond resolution, (ii) extract from these trajectories hitherto physical parameters, such as NP-NP interaction potentials and self-assembly kinetic pathways, based on high-throughput statistical analysis of these trajectories, and (iii) quantify how diverse stimuli, such as temperature and solvent polarity, affect phase transition dynamics in systems of NPs with reconfigurable polymer coronas, moving towards systems that adapt their structure and functions entirely from the bottom-up. This approach will help establish a quantitative building block-nanoscale interaction-targeted structure relationship for predictive materials design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The research goal of the project is to understand how the Brownian motions of nanosized building blocks suspended in liquid media translate to highly-organized, reconfigurable materials with unique potential for miniaturization and exhibiting quantum confinement properties determined by the structures they assemble into. The essential gap we aim to fill is to resolve their kinetic pathways of self-assembly and reconfiguration in liquids, with the unparallel nanometer and millisecond resolutions. In this project, we have utilized and customized the new tool of liquid-phase transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to obtain a previously inaccessible type of experimental dataset, showing the real-time, real-space evolution of an ensemble of anisotropically shaped nanoparticles in liquids. We have also developed machine learning (ML) based high throughput analysis method to extract quantitative measurements of the physical parameters (e.g., phase transition coordinate, nanoscale interactions) inaccessible to other techniques that describe how final structures are dynamically selected.

As to intellectual merit, over the five-year duration of the project, we have made major strides in resolving and understanding the self-assembly pathways of nanoparticles (NPs). NPs are our system of focus in this proposal because they exhibit a host of rich optical, electronic, and catalytic properties, both individually and collectively, and they have tunable properties to be systematically studied as model systems. We have also pushed the technical limits of liquid-phase TEM imaging to resolve the ensemble NP solution dynamics at single NP level, thus defining a paradigm shift in NP assembly studies. Supported by this grant, we have published a total of 14 peer-reviewed book chapters and papers, including those on journals such as Nature Materials, Nature Communications, ACS Central Science, and JACS. These studies showcase our method integrating liquid-phase TEM imaging, single NP tracking, analysis based on statistical mechanics, and course-grained interaction modeling. We also discussed our vision of the field through invited reviews on Acc. Mater. Res. and MRS bulletin, and invited viewpoint on Nano Lett.

As to broader impacts, on scientific innovations, this project enables important new experiments and understanding in condensed matter physics, reconfigurable nano- and meso-materials (where the missing link is nanoscale dynamics), and TEM imaging. Relevant systems to societal needs include light-weight materials, solar energy conversion, advanced energy storage, advanced therapeutics, etc. Doing so with the rigorous quantification proposed here, this research can go beyond its specific scientific goals by providing the materials methods and parameters for other laboratories to use these generalizable techniques in service of their own ends. For example, the analysis codes and kinetic pathways have been made available to the public, so scientists can use them for interpreting their data on various materials systems. The interparticle interaction we experimentally determine can serve as input parameters for simulation to predict new assembly structures. We also extract the correlation between NP shapes and their interaction dynamics and, subsequently, the final structures they adopt. This relationship can lead to design rules for the fabrication of targeted structures with desired properties and functionalities on demand.

On the education side, we have proceeded extensively on implementing the "tri-M lab" including Modular lab demos, a Mobile game app, and Movies to promote self-assembly materials research to the general public. Specifically, the lab demos have been performed to both the 2019 Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology Open House, and the Grainger engineering you scholars program in the summer of 2019. In the latter of which, we trained a high school student on how to use ML to work on the analysis and processing of liquid-phase TEM images. Since 2022, we have become part of mentoring Merit undergraduate students through a collaborative learning program offered by the Chemistry, Mathematics, Integrative Biology and Molecular and Cellular Biology Departments. We are working with two Chemistry Freshman mentees who are underrepresented in STEM fields. We have provided demos to students at Booker T. Washington Elementary School. For the Movies, we have continuously uploaded movies on our work in our YouTube channel and news highlights of our work, as well as the PI's talks. For the Mobile game app, since the advent of the AI, we changed our strategy to make AI available for liquid-phase TEM studies and make the involved data processing codes completely available to the community through our Github websites.


Last Modified: 06/29/2023
Modified by: Qian Chen
